Description: Rim and body sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl with slightly protruding squared rim and slight carination at height of lower edge of figured zone; white slip; interior and top of rim reserved; exterior: short diagonals at rim; below, black-figure decoration consisting of lion (part of mane with added red, lower jaw and foreleg remaining), to right; pendant and full rosettes with red centres as filling ornament; below, black band.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Group A of the Sphinx and Lion Style. The decoration on the vases from this group is the most elaborate. The rosette has a standard cogwheel shape and the figures are carefully drawn and details are expertly incised.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 146, p. 311, no. 1294, pl. 167)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 83, no. 35, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2122) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
